metadata.h1: People’s Opinion of Australia’s Prime Minister
metadata.description: People's opinion of Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison (ScoMo) by using python twitter data sentiment analysis.

all_paragraphs: “Scott Morrison’s holiday is not the problem, his lack of leadership on the bushfires is!”
“Australia is scared and confused about coronavirus. Is Scott Morrison the leader we need for this grave moment??”

Scott Morrison(ScoMo) is Australia’s 30th prime minister and the leader of the liberal party since 2018. I am not supporting any political party but, during my stay in Australia, I never heard a good thing about our prime minister and I’m certain most people don’t like him.
I have been interested in knowing what the majority of people think about ScoMo. But where can I find such information? There is a source we can use to grab data. It’s Twitter.

Twitter is a microblogging system that allows you to send and receive short posts called tweets. Tweets can be up to 140 characters long and can include links to relevant websites and resources. It’s a social media platforms with 145 million daily active users and 500 million tweets sent daily.
Now we know where to find data. But,
That’s what I’m going to discuss in this article.
First, we need to have a basic idea of sentiment analysis.
In essence, it is the process of determining the emotional tone behind a series of words, used to gain an understanding of the the attitudes, opinions and emotions expressed within an online mention.
Ok! Enough waiting. Let’s dive into the code,
Click here to view my complete project on GitHub.

I managed to collect 43554 tweets between the period of 01/04/20 and 09/04/20. I’ve used all the tweets for the analysis. Twitter standard API only allows us to backdate for ten days. If the tweet volume is high related to the keywords, we will be able to collect a higher number of tweets.

This step is crucial when we’re dealing with data. Extracted data exists in a raw format, which is not feasible for the analysis. That’s why we need to clean the data and convert then into a clean data set. Here I’m using the following two libraries to achieve the task.
Preprocessor — Preprocessor is a preprocessing library for tweet data written in Python. This library makes it easy to clean, parse, or tokenize the tweets.

re — re is Python’s Regular Expressions (RegEx) library, which takes care of parsing strings and efficiently modifying them without having to iterate through the characters comprising the particular string explicitly.

Punctuations do not help when analyzing. It is better to remove them from the text just as we removed using the clean() function.

A stop word is a commonly used word (such as “the”, “a”, “an”, “in”) in the English language. They do not add value to the context. We would not want these words to take up space in our database, or taking up the valuable processing time.
Sometimes, you would need to remove the words that are unique, like names, brands, product names, and some of the noise characters, such as HTML leftouts. This is considered a rare word removal.
Lemmatization is a process that seeks to analyze the intended meaning of a word rather than it’s base form.

Here we have come to the final part of the work.
I have managed to clean the tweet text in a more meaningful way than the original version, which will be helpful to recognize the sentiment of the text.

TextBlob is a Python (2 and 3) library for processing textual data. It provides a simple API for diving into common natural language processing (NLP) tasks such as part-of-speech tagging, noun phrase extraction, sentiment analysis, classification, translation, and more.
Read the processed_data.csv to a Dataframe

Polarity, also known as orientation is the emotion expressed in the sentence. It can be positive, negative or neutral. Subjectivity is when text is an informative article that must be analyzed in context.

Polarity is a float which lies in the range of [-1,1] where 1 means positive statement and -1 means a negative statement. Subjective sentences generally refer to personal opinion, emotion or judgment, whereas objective refers to factual information. Subjectivity is also a float which lies in the range of [0,1].
The sentiment function of textblob returns two properties, polarity, and subjectivity.
Calculated polarity and subjectivity are added to the dataset.

The result of the analysis is as follows. It shows 50.19% of the people have neutral opinions (either negative or positive) on ScoMo, while 32.36% of people have positive opinions and 17.45% have negative opinions.

According to the analysis, a higher number of people (50%) shows a neutral opinion on ScoMo. This result can be changed if we could gather data for a more extended period rather than ten days. Moreover, the fact such as the current situation of the world and recent events affect the tweet’s behaviour.

I’ve only used the text of the tweet. Other attributes such as date/time, geo locations can be used for further analysis. Furthermore, we can observe what are the frequently used words and look for patterns and train a model for future use.
